name: Dihydrogen Monoxide
description: The most abundant compound on Earth. Essential for all known forms of life. H₂O consists of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to one oxygen atom. Its three primary states (ice, water, steam) are commonly observed in Earth's biosphere.

dipole.description: Water is a polar molecule with a strong dipole moment, making it an excellent solvent

pH.description: Pure water is neutral at 25°C (slightly acidic due to dissolved CO₂ from air)

solid.name: Ice
solid.description: Solid form of water. Less dense than liquid water due to hydrogen bonding crystalline structure.

liquid.name: Water
liquid.description: Liquid form of water. Most common state on Earth. Excellent solvent for biological processes.

gas.name: Steam
gas.description: Gaseous form of water. Invisible water vapor at low concentrations, visible vapor clouds when condensing.

triplePoint.description: The unique temperature and pressure where ice, water, and steam coexist in equilibrium. This defines the Kelvin scale.

criticalPoint.description: Beyond this point, the distinction between liquid and gas phases disappears. Water becomes supercritical.

standardBoilingPoint.description: Temperature at which liquid water converts to steam at standard atmospheric pressure

standardFreezingPoint.description: Temperature at which liquid water converts to ice at standard atmospheric pressure

biologicalSignificance: Essential for photosynthesis and cellular respiration

metadata.educationalNotes: Water is unique in that its solid form (ice) floats on its liquid form - this is rare in nature and critical for aquatic ecosystems. The strong hydrogen bonding gives water unusual properties like high surface tension, high heat capacity, and high heat of vaporization.
